instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3482: What is 820-3482? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3302: What is 820-3302? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: imac 21.5" 2013 - similar boards
threads.message:
I'm working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3482</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board but can't find the schematic anywhere.  Does anyone know if any of the older iMac 21.5 boards are close enough?  I mainly work on macbook pros and it seems the schematics don't change too much from year to year (just the board views).

thanks,
Paul

threads.title: imac 21.5" 2013 - similar boards
threads.message: Probably the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> from 2012. What is the issue with the board?

threads.title: imac 21.5" 2013 - similar boards
threads.message: 120V was run through one of the USB ports - less damage then I thought I would see (someone stuck the end of a USB cord into an outlet).  I removed some of the blown USB port chips but didn't want to go any further until I could check for STG/etc.  No boot but I see a green light on the MB.

threads.title: imac 21.5" 2013 - similar boards
threads.message: I would say this board is totally fried.....

threads.title: imac 21.5" 2013 - similar boards
threads.message: Would totally agree - told the customer the same but hoping to spend a couple of hours on it and maybe pull a rabbit out of the hat ;>

threads.title: imac 21.5" 2013 - similar boards
threads.message: Can I advice you not to waste your time?
